The reason why the exception is not thrown when the size of the ArrayList is equal to 2 is because the Iterator.next() method is used to retrieve the next element in the iterator, which moves the internal cursor of the iterator to the next element. In the case of an ArrayList with only two elements, the internal cursor is already pointing to the second element, so calling Iterator.next() does not throw an exception.

However, when a new element is added to the ArrayList while iterating over it, the internal cursor is moved to the new element, and calling Iterator.next() again will throw a ConcurrentModificationException. This is because the iteration is occurring concurrently with the modification of the ArrayList, and the iterator is no longer pointing to the correct element.

To avoid this exception, you can use the Iterator.remove() method instead of the for-each loop, which does not modify the iterator and will not throw a ConcurrentModificationException.
